questions.question: What is the **root** of the default class hierarchy (superclass of Object)?
questions.explanation: BasicObject is the top of the hierarchy. Object inherits from BasicObject. Most classes inherit from Object. BasicObject has very few methods.

questions.question: Which **module** is included in Object and provides methods like puts, p, raise?
questions.explanation: Kernel is included in Object, so every object has Kernel's instance methods (puts, p, raise, gets, rand, etc.). They appear as global methods because main is the receiver.

questions.question: What does **Object#class** return?

options.A: The Class object of which the object is an instance
options.B: The class name as a string

questions.explanation: obj.class returns the Class object (e.g. "hello".class => String). For the name as a string use obj.class.name.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
puts 5.class
puts 5.0.class
```
questions.explanation: In Ruby 3, integers are Integer (Fixnum/Bignum were unified). 5.class is Integer, 5.0.class is Float.

questions.question: Which module do you **include** to get <, <=, ==, >=, >, between? (by defining <=>)?
questions.explanation: Define <=> (spaceship) and include Comparable; you get <, <=, ==, >=, >, and between?. Used by String, Numeric, Time.

questions.question: What does **Enumerable** require you to define to get map, select, find?
questions.explanation: Include Enumerable and define each; you get map, select, find, reduce, etc. Array, Hash, Range include Enumerable.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
s = "hello"
puts s.length
puts s.size
```
questions.explanation: String#length and String#size are aliases; both return the character count. So 5, 5.

questions.question: What does **String#split** return by default (no argument)?
questions.explanation: split with no argument (or nil) splits on whitespace and returns an array of words. split("") splits into characters; split("\n") into lines.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
arr = [1, 2, 3]
arr << 4
puts arr.last
```
questions.explanation: << appends to the array. arr becomes [1, 2, 3, 4]. last returns the last element, so 4.

questions.question: What does **Array#compact** do?

options.A: Removes all nil elements and returns a new array

questions.explanation: compact returns a new array with all nil elements removed. compact! mutates in place. uniq removes duplicates; flatten flattens nesting.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
h = { a: 1, b: 2 }
puts h.keys.inspect
puts h.key?(:a)
```
questions.explanation: Hash#keys returns an array of keys (symbols here). key?(:a) returns true if the key exists. So [:a, :b] and true.

questions.question: What does **Hash#merge** do?

options.A: Returns a new hash combining both; duplicate keys use the argument's value

questions.explanation: h1.merge(h2) returns a new hash. Keys in h2 override keys in h1. merge! (or update) mutates the receiver.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
puts [1, 2, 3].include?(2)
puts [1, 2, 3].member?(3)
```
questions.explanation: include? and member? are aliases (from Enumerable). They return true if the element is in the collection. So true, true.

questions.question: What does **Kernel#puts** do differently from **Kernel#p**?

options.A: puts calls to_s and adds newline; p calls inspect and adds newline
options.D: puts returns nil; p returns the object

questions.explanation: puts obj prints obj.to_s and a newline (multiple args = multiple lines). p obj prints obj.inspect and a newline (better for debugging). Both return nil.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
puts [1, 2, 3].find { |n| n > 2 }
puts [1, 2, 3].select { |n| n > 2 }.inspect
```
questions.explanation: find (Enumerable) returns the first element for which the block is truthy → 3. select returns all such elements → [3].

questions.question: What does **Integer#times** do?

options.A: Yields 0 to n-1 to the block; returns self

questions.explanation: n.times { |i| ... } yields i = 0, 1, ..., n-1. Returns the integer (self). So 3.times yields 0, 1, 2.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
puts "hello".upcase
puts "HELLO".downcase
```
questions.explanation: upcase converts to uppercase; downcase to lowercase. So HELLO and hello.

questions.question: What does **Array#shift** do?

options.A: Removes and returns the first element
options.C: Adds an element at the beginning

questions.explanation: shift removes and returns the first element. pop removes the last. unshift adds at the beginning.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
h = { "a" => 1, "b" => 2 }
puts h["a"]
puts h[:a]
```
questions.explanation: Hash keys are compared by eql? and hash. String and Symbol are different keys. h["a"] is 1; h[:a] is nil (no symbol key).

questions.question: What does **Enumerable#reduce** (or inject) do?

options.A: Combines all elements using a block (and optional initial value)

questions.explanation: reduce(init) { |acc, el| ... } (or inject) runs the block for each element; acc is the accumulated value. [1,2,3].reduce(0) { |s,n| s+n } => 6.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
puts (-5).abs
puts 5.abs
```
questions.explanation: Numeric#abs returns the absolute value. So (-5).abs is 5 and 5.abs is 5.

questions.question: What does **String#gsub** return?

options.A: A new string with all matches replaced

questions.explanation: gsub(pattern, replacement) or gsub(pattern) { } returns a new string with all matches replaced. gsub! mutates the receiver.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
puts [3, 1, 2].sort.inspect
puts [3, 1, 2].sort { |a, b| b <=> a }.inspect
```
questions.explanation: sort uses <=> (ascending by default) → [1, 2, 3]. The block b <=> a reverses order → [3, 2, 1].

questions.question: What does **Kernel#raise** do?
questions.explanation: raise (or fail) raises an exception. raise "msg" raises RuntimeError; raise SomeError, "msg" raises the given error class.

questions.question: Which are **Enumerable** methods (available when you define each)?
questions.explanation: map, select, find (and reduce, count, etc.) come from Enumerable. length/size may come from the class itself (e.g. Array#length) or Enumerable#count; typically length is on Array. So A, B, D are Enumerable; length is often a direct method on the collection.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
puts "  hello  ".strip
puts "hello".strip
```
questions.explanation: strip removes leading and trailing whitespace. So "  hello  ".strip is "hello"; "hello".strip is "hello" (unchanged).

questions.question: What does **Hash#fetch** do when the key is missing (and no default given)?
questions.explanation: fetch(key) returns the value for key. If key is missing, it raises KeyError (or returns the second argument if provided: fetch(key, default)).

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
puts "hello".start_with?("he")
puts "hello".end_with?("lo")
```
questions.explanation: start_with? and end_with? return true if the string starts/ends with the given prefix/suffix. So true, true.

questions.question: What does **Array#uniq** do?

options.A: Returns a new array with duplicate elements removed

questions.explanation: uniq returns a new array with only the first occurrence of each value. uniq! mutates. compact removes nil; uniq removes duplicates.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
puts (1..5).min
puts (1..5).max
```
questions.explanation: Range (and Enumerable) provide min and max. For 1..5, min is 1 and max is 5.

questions.question: What does **String#chars** return?
questions.explanation: chars returns an array of one-character strings. "hello".chars => ["h", "e", "l", "l", "o"]. For bytes use bytes.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
arr = [10, 20, 30]
puts arr.first
puts arr.last
```
questions.explanation: first returns the first element; last returns the last. So 10 and 30. Works for Array and other Enumerables (e.g. Range).

questions.question: What does **Hash#values** return?
questions.explanation: values returns an array of the hash's values. keys returns keys; to_a returns [ [k,v], ... ]. So h.values => [1, 2, 3] for {a:1, b:2, c:3}.
any? returns true if the block is true for at least one element (3 > 2). all? returns true if the block is true for every element (all > 0). So true, true.

questions.question: What does **Array#pop** do?

options.A: Removes and returns the last element
options.C: Returns the last element without removing
options.D: Adds an element at the end

questions.explanation: pop removes and returns the last element. shift removes the first. push (or <<) adds at the end; unshift adds at the beginning.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
puts "hello".empty?
puts "".empty?
```
questions.explanation: empty? returns true if the string has length 0. "hello" is not empty; "" is empty. So false, true.

questions.question: What does **Kernel#rand** return (with no argument)?
questions.explanation: rand with no argument returns a random float >= 0 and < 1. rand(10) returns a random integer in 0...10. rand(max) gives integer in [0, max).

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
puts [1, [2, 3], 4].flatten.inspect
```
questions.explanation: flatten returns a new array with all elements recursively flattened to one level (by default). So [1, [2, 3], 4].flatten => [1, 2, 3, 4].

questions.question: What does **String#to_i** do?

options.A: Converts leading numeric part to an integer

questions.explanation: to_i parses leading characters as an integer; trailing non-numeric is ignored. "42".to_i => 42, "42abc".to_i => 42, "abc".to_i => 0. Integer("42") is stricter (raises on invalid).

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
h = { a: 1, b: 2 }
puts h.has_value?(2)
puts h.value?(1)
```
questions.explanation: has_value? and value? are aliases; they return true if the hash has that value. So has_value?(2) and value?(1) are both true.

questions.question: What does **Enumerable#count** return (with no block)?
questions.explanation: count with no block returns the number of elements (e.g. array length). count { |x| ... } returns how many elements make the block true.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
puts (1..5).cover?(3)
puts (1...5).cover?(5)
```
questions.explanation: cover? checks if the value is within the range. 3 is in 1..5 => true. 5 is not in 1...5 (exclusive end) => false.

questions.question: What does **Numeric#round** do (with no argument)?
questions.explanation: round rounds to the nearest integer (0.5 rounds up in default mode). round(n) rounds to n decimal places. ceil rounds up; floor rounds down.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
puts [1, 2, 3].reverse.inspect
puts "hello".reverse
```
questions.explanation: Array#reverse and String#reverse return a new reversed array/string. [1,2,3].reverse => [3,2,1]; "hello".reverse => "olleh".

questions.question: What does **Object#nil?** return?

options.A: true only for the object nil

questions.explanation: nil? is defined so that only the object nil returns true. So nil.nil? => true; false.nil? => false; 0.nil? => false. Used to check for nil specifically.
